reasoning: The critique targets an important conceptual load-bearing term (“accurate/correct” moral view) used in defining WAM-convergence and in the conditional claim that WAM-convergence would yield a mostly-great future. If the notion of ‘accuracy’ can’t be held fixed across the metaethical cases the essay considers, then some comparisons and inferences about (non-)convergence are harder to evaluate, so centrality is moderate. However, the essay often signals perspective-dependence (“by their lights,” ‘preferred view’) and could fairly easily regiment the terminology (e.g., define ‘accurate’ as ‘correct on moral realism, and matches a specified idealization/endorsement target on antirealism’), so the critique doesn’t substantially undercut the main substantive thrust (skepticism about WAM-convergence; conditional optimism via trade). Thus strength is only modest. Most of what the critique says is true: there is some slippage between ‘single determinate correct target’ talk and agent-relative/anti-realist framing, and this can blur what is being predicted. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Shifting definitions of moral accuracy undermine the convergence argument
